stem: Why are two orthogonal radiographic views (e.g., AP and lateral) routinely obtained for upper‑limb injuries?

choices.A: To reduce radiation dose per image
choices.D: To reduce superimposition and better localize pathology in 3D
choices.E: To avoid the need for CT or MRI entirely

rationale_correct: Orthogonal views reduce superimposition and allow better localization; a single projection can miss or obscure findings.

rationale_distractors.A: Two views increase total dose compared to one.
rationale_distractors.B: Soft‑tissue contrast is modality‑limited on radiographs.
rationale_distractors.C: Motion control is achieved by technique and patient cooperation, not number of views.
rationale_distractors.E: Additional modalities may still be indicated depending on the injury.

evidence.citation: Rhodes D. Learning objectives for Radiology of the Upper Limb. 2018/2021.
